references: The remainder of this work is structured as follows. Section 2 builds a common foundation on which we will base our overview of Deep Meta-Learning techniques. Sections 3, 4, and 5 cover the main metric-, model-, and optimization-based meta-learning techniques, respectively. Section 6 provides a helicopter view of the field and summarizes the key challenges and open questions. TableÂ 1 gives an overview of notation that we will use throughout this paper.

S2.T2.caption: Table 2: High-level overview of the three Deep Meta-Learning categories, i.e., i)Â metric-, ii)Â model-, and iii)Â optimization-based techniques, and their main strengths and weaknesses. Recall that ğ’¯jsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘—\mathcal{T}_{j} is a task, Dğ’¯jtâ€‹rsubscriptsuperscriptğ·ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘—D^{tr}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}} the corresponding support set, kğœ½â€‹(ğ’™,ğ’™i)subscriptğ‘˜ğœ½ğ’™subscriptğ’™ğ‘–k_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{x}_{i}) a kernel function returning the similarity between the two inputs ğ’™ğ’™\boldsymbol{x} and ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–\boldsymbol{x}_{i}, yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} are true labels for known inputs ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–\boldsymbol{x}_{i}, Î¸ğœƒ\theta are base-learner parameters, and gğ‹subscriptğ‘”ğ‹g_{\boldsymbol{\varphi}} is a (learned) optimizer with parameters ğ‹ğ‹\boldsymbol{\varphi}.
references:
To help give an overview of the methods, we draw your attention to the following tables.
TableÂ 2 summarizes the three categories and provides key ideas, and strengths of the approaches. The terms and technical details are explained more fully in the remainder of this paper. TableÂ 3 contains an overview of all techniques that are discussed further on.

TableÂ 2 provides a concise, tabular overview of these approaches. Many techniques have been proposed for each one of the categories, and the underlying ideas may vary greatly, even within the same category. TableÂ 3, therefore, provides an overview of all methods and key ideas that we have discussed in this work, together with their applicability to supervised learning (SL) and reinforcement learning (RL) settings, key ideas, and benchmarks that were used for testing them.
TableÂ 5 displays an overview of the 1- and 5-shot classification performances (reported by the original authors) of the techniques on the frequently used miniImageNet benchmark.
Moreover, it displays the used backbone (feature extraction module) as well as the final classification mechanism.
From this table, it becomes clear that the 5-shot performance is typically better than the 1-shot performance, indicating that data scarcity is a large bottleneck for achieving good performance.
Moreover, there is a strong relationship between the expressivity of the backbone and the performance.
That is, deeper backbones tend to give rise to better classification performance.
The best performance is achieved by MetaOptNet, yielding a 1-shot accuracy of 64.0964.0964.09% and a 5-shot accuracy of 80.0080.0080.00%.
Note however that MetaOptNet used a deeper backbone than most of the other techniques.

S2.T3.caption: Table 3: Overview of the discussed Deep Meta-Learning techniques. The table is partitioned into three sections, i.e., metric-, model-, and optimization-based techniques. All methods in one section adhere to the key idea of its corresponding category, which is mentioned in bold font. The columns RL and Bench show whether the techniques are applicable to reinforcement learning settings and the used benchmarks for testing the performance of the techniques. Note that all techniques are applicable to supervised learning, with the exception of RMLs. The benchmark column displays which benchmarks from SectionÂ 2.2.2 were used in the paper proposing the technique. The used coding scheme for this column is the following. 1: Omniglot, 2: miniImageNet, 3: tieredImageNet, 4: CIFAR-100, 5: CIFAR-FS, 6: CIFAR-10, 7: CUB, 8: MNIST, â€œ-": used other evaluation method that are non-standard in Deep Meta-Learning and thus not covered in SectionÂ 2.2.2. Used abbreviations: â€œopt.": optimization, â€œdiff.": differentiable, â€œbench.": benchmarks.
S2.T3.table:
Name RL Key idea Bench.
Metric-based Input similarity -
â€‰ Siamese networks âœ— Two-input, shared-weight, class identity network 1, 8
â€‰ Matching networks âœ— Learn input embeddings for cosine-similarity weighted predictions 1, 2
â€‰ Prototypical networks âœ— Input embeddings for class prototype clustering 1, 2, 7
â€‰ Relation networks âœ— Learn input embeddings and similarity metric 1, 2, 7
â€‰ ARC âœ— LSTM-based input fusion through interleaved glimpses 1, 2
â€‰ GNN âœ— Propagate label information to unlabeled inputs in a graph 1, 2
Model-based Internal and stateful latent task representations -
â€‰ Reccurrent ml. âœ“ Deploy Recurrent networks on RL problems -
â€‰ MANNs âœ— External short-term memory module for fast learning 1
â€‰ Meta networks âœ“ Fast reparameterization of base-learner by distinct meta-learner 1, 2
â€‰ SNAIL âœ“ Attention mechanism coupled with temporal convolutions 1, 2
â€‰ CNP âœ— Condition predictive model on embedded contextual task data 1, 8
â€‰ Neural stat. âœ— Similarity between latent task embeddings 1, 8
Opt.-based Optimize for fast task-specific adaptation -
â€‰ LSTM optimizer âœ— RNN proposing weight updates for base-leaner 6, 8
â€‰ LSTM ml. âœ“ Embed base-learner parameters in cell state of LSTM 2
â€‰ RL optimizer âœ— View optimization as RL problem 4, 6
â€‰ MAML âœ“ Learn initialization weights ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta} for fast adaptation 1, 2
â€‰ iMAML âœ“ Approx. higher-order gradients, independent of optimization path 1, 2
â€‰ Meta-SGD âœ“ Learn both the initialization and updates 1, 2
â€‰ Reptile âœ“ Move initialization towards task-specific updated weights 1, 2
â€‰ LEO âœ— Optimize in lower-dimensional latent parameter space 2, 3
â€‰ Online MAML âœ— Accumulate task data for MAML-like training 4, 8
â€‰ LLAMA âœ— Maintain probability distribution over post-update parameters ğœ½jâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğœ½â€²ğ‘—\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}_{j} 2
â€‰ PLATIPUS âœ— Learn a probability distribution over weight initializations ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta} -
â€‰ BMAML âœ“ Learn multiple initializations ğš¯ğš¯\boldsymbol{\Theta}, jointly optimized by SVGD 2
â€‰ Diff. solvers âœ— Learn input embeddings for simple base-learners 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

To help give an overview of the methods, we draw your attention to the following tables.
TableÂ 2 summarizes the three categories and provides key ideas, and strengths of the approaches. The terms and technical details are explained more fully in the remainder of this paper. TableÂ 3 contains an overview of all techniques that are discussed further on.

TableÂ 2 provides a concise, tabular overview of these approaches. Many techniques have been proposed for each one of the categories, and the underlying ideas may vary greatly, even within the same category. TableÂ 3, therefore, provides an overview of all methods and key ideas that we have discussed in this work, together with their applicability to supervised learning (SL) and reinforcement learning (RL) settings, key ideas, and benchmarks that were used for testing them.
TableÂ 5 displays an overview of the 1- and 5-shot classification performances (reported by the original authors) of the techniques on the frequently used miniImageNet benchmark.
Moreover, it displays the used backbone (feature extraction module) as well as the final classification mechanism.
From this table, it becomes clear that the 5-shot performance is typically better than the 1-shot performance, indicating that data scarcity is a large bottleneck for achieving good performance.
Moreover, there is a strong relationship between the expressivity of the backbone and the performance.
That is, deeper backbones tend to give rise to better classification performance.
The best performance is achieved by MetaOptNet, yielding a 1-shot accuracy of 64.0964.0964.09% and a 5-shot accuracy of 80.0080.0080.00%.
Note however that MetaOptNet used a deeper backbone than most of the other techniques.

S6.T5.caption: Table 5: Comparison of the accuracy scores of the covered meta-learning techniques on 1- and 5-shot miniImageNet classification. Scores are taken from the original papers. The Â±plus-or-minus\pm indicates the 95% confidence interval. The backbone is the used feature extraction module. The classifier column shows the final layer(s) that were used to transform the features into class predictions. Used abbreviations: â€œsim.": similarity, â€œAdj.": adjusted, and â€œdist.": distance, â€œlog.": logistic, â€œregr.": regression, â€œml.": meta-learner, â€œopt.": optimization.

Many techniques have been proposed for each one of the categories, and the underlying ideas may vary greatly, even within the same category. TableÂ 3, therefore, provides an overview of all methods and key ideas that we have discussed in this work, together with their applicability to supervised learning (SL) and reinforcement learning (RL) settings, key ideas, and benchmarks that were used for testing them.
TableÂ 5 displays an overview of the 1- and 5-shot classification performances (reported by the original authors) of the techniques on the frequently used miniImageNet benchmark.
Moreover, it displays the used backbone (feature extraction module) as well as the final classification mechanism.
From this table, it becomes clear that the 5-shot performance is typically better than the 1-shot performance, indicating that data scarcity is a large bottleneck for achieving good performance.
Moreover, there is a strong relationship between the expressivity of the backbone and the performance.
